text: (audience applauds)
Thank you guys very much.
Before I start my talk, I wanted to say how excited I
am to be here with all of you guys.
I've been a part of the Effect
community for a very long time.
And the fact that we're all here is just amazing to me.
A huge shout out to all the organizers of this conference.
So if we could just give a quick
round of applause for all of them.
(audience applauds)
Thank you, guys.
(audience applauds)
So I'm Maxwell Brown.
I've been a part of the community for a while now.
And this is my lightning talk,
which is entitled Effect CLI
a love letter to developers tired of settling for less.
So before I get started with
talking about all the cool things
that we have in Effect CLI, I wanted
to talk for a moment about my motivation
behind building this library.
So you folks might think that I built this library
because I wanted to improve the
developer experience on the command
line.
Or maybe at the time, I wanted to
build the first application level
framework for Effect.
We didn't have any at that point.
But the reality is actually a lot simpler.
I'm just kind of lazy.
And I don't mean lazy in the
sense that I'm not willing to do work.
I mean I'm lazy when it comes to the boring things
that we as developers are often saddled with having to do.
Even though we might not necessarily have to.
And our software can maybe help with some of that.
So at the time before writing Effect CLI,
I had a need for a CLI framework.
I wasn't happy with any of the
frameworks I found out there.
And so Effect CLI was born.
And today, I'm really hoping to show all of you
how you can improve your
productivity by 10x on the command line.
Yes, 10x.
By utilizing Effect CLI for your CLI applications.
But to do that, I needed a good example.
Now some of you might know,
because I can't stop talking about it,
that I recently became a father.
(audience applauds)
Thank you.
And I've made it recently... very recently...
I've made it my mission in life to become
the supreme undisputed grandmaster of the dad joke.
And so I thought it would be
very appropriate for our example
application today to be a CLI
that fetches dad jokes for us.
So you can see here and I've affectionately
titled our CLI the dadinator.
Our CLI has two commands.
We've got the random command, subcommand,
which fetches us a random dad joke.
And then we've got the search subcommand,
which fetches us a dad joke based on some search
term that we provide.
Optionally with a limit... but let's be honest,
when would we ever want to limit the number of dad jokes
we have access to?
And before I keep going with this talk,
maybe we can take a quick peek at how the CLI works.
You guys can all see that.
Maybe I'll make it a bit bigger.
One second.
OK.
So perhaps we'll fetch a random dad joke first.
Thank you.
Actually.
Is this one working?
Hello?
OK.
And recently, I believe Sebastian
made some significant quality
of life improvements to the CLI.
So let's see if it works.
OK, daddy.
We've no risk one yet.
I wear a stethoscope so that in the medical emergency
I can teach people a valuable lesson about assumptions.
[LAUGHTER]
OK.
Don't worry.
There'll be more at the end.
There'll be more at the end.
So with that, let's take a look at
I want to start by taking a look at the API that
Effect CLI provides.
I know it may not be the sexiest feature of the library,
but we provide an extremely easy to use,
highly composable and type safe CLI from this library.
Not to toot my own horn.
But the full spec of the dadinator CLI that we just
used is on this slide.
And maybe we can go through it very quickly.
So we've got an option, a command line option,
that we're specifying here, which is a limit, which
is an integer.
We're giving it an alias.
We're providing a description.
And we're setting a default. And now we've
got the full spec for our limit option.
We've also got a command line argument,
so what we basically use to represent positional arguments
in Effect CLI, which we're calling
term, which is a piece of text.
And this also has a description associated with it.
And we're providing both the limit and the term
to our search subcommand.
And in our search subcommand, you
can see that we're attaching a handler as well.
And in the handler, we receive the parsed value of limit
and term, which we can use to perform some logic in order
to search for our DAD jokes.
We also have the random command here,
which attaches a handler to fetch random DAD jokes.
And then both of these subcommands
get attached to the parent dadinator command, the root
command, the registered subcommands.
And with 20 lines of code, we've fully
specified our CLI application.
And all we have to deal with is the actual application
level logic, which is pretty cool.
The other thing that this library gives us,
because we've specified our full CLI app in code,
we can do a lot of things for the developer.
I mentioned that I'm very lazy.
One of the things that I hate
doing is writing documentation.
And because you've specified the full structure of your CLI
application in code, we can actually
generate all the help documentation
for the CLI for you.
So I've taken a small snippet of the search subcommand
documentation here.
You can see we can generate a full usage statement
for the commands that you specify.
We also have the documentation for the arguments
that you've provided, as well as the options.
And in addition, you'll notice that the custom descriptions
provided also show up in the generated documentation.
But we don't stop there.
We also generate for you completion scripts.
In fact
(audience applauds)
Thank you.
Effect CLI is, I think, one of the only TypeScript CLI
frameworks out there that can generate completion scripts
successfully for all of the major shells that exist.
I might be missing a few.
Some of you use weird shells.
I don't know.
And the other thing about the completion scripts
that we generate is that they're fully static.
A lot of the CLI frameworks out there
have to re-invoke your CLI application
to get the generated completions out.
We can do it statically
because of the way that you build up
your CLI application.
So oftentimes, the completions on the command line
become pretty performant.
Maybe we can take 30 seconds, and I can show you folks.
So thank you.
So we can very quickly start up a fish shell.
You're welcome, Johannes.
I swore to myself I wouldn't mention Johannes in my talk.
And here we are.
So we can basically use the completions flag, which
is available with all CLI applications,
specify the shell that we want, and pipe it out
to a file that will hold the shell script.
Obviously, this would usually be going
in whatever the completions directory is
appropriate for your shell.
But once we've done this, for our little example here,
we can source these completions.
And just like that, we've got generated completions
for our CLI that we can tab through,
because I'm also too lazy to type.
And again, flags will show up here.
I'm working on positional arguments as well.
We don't quite handle those extremely well yet.
But you kind of get the idea
thank you very much, Anjana
of some of the other things that we can generate for you.
And the feature of Effect CLI
that I'm personally most proud
of is also the feature that highlights my dedication
to not writing documentation.
With Wizard Mode and Effect CLI, you
don't even need documentation, because you
can have your CLI applications walk your users through them
automatically.
And I think maybe this is best exemplified
by just me showing you.
So let's exit our fish shell, because it really
uses fish anyways.
I think I can do this one-handed.
So with every CLI application, with every Effect CLI
application, we get this wizard flag.
And once we start the wizard, you're
automatically dropped into a prompt-based wizard, which
will guide your users through your CLI application.
The prompts that are generated are specific to your CLI.
They're completely based on the commands and options
and arguments that you provide.
And so maybe we can take a
quick walk through the dadinator CLI
from the perspective of a user who's never used it before.
So looking at the instructions, this Wizard Mode
is going to take us through constructing commands
for the dadinator CLI.
We need to answer all the prompts for the wizard.
And you can see at the bottom,
the first thing we need to do
is, because we have subcommands and we don't have options
or arguments on the root command,
the first thing we need to do is select which
command we want to execute.
So let's try the search subcommands this time.
Like I said, so once you're in a command wizard,
the wizard will detect whether you
have options or arguments for that particular command
and will prompt you to provide those things.
In this case, like I said, limit, it's an integer.
It's the maximum number of DAD jokes we want to fetch.
Why would you ever want to limit this?
I don't know.
So let's just go with the defaults.
I haven't tested this.
And then we also have a command line argument.
So you can see now we're dropped into the ARGS Wizard.
We need to provide a search term.
And again, the help documentation
that's present with the help flag
is presented to the user here as well.
So maybe we can find some jokes about hipsters.
Anybody else have any better search terms we can use?
Yeah. Oh, good idea.
Oh my god, I don't know how many DAD jokes
this is going to bring back.
So once you're done with wizard mode,
we have the option of... if you noticed as we were executing
the wizard mode, we do have the command
that we're building up provided to us.
And it incrementally updates as we answer the prompts
in wizard mode.
And then once we're finished, we're
presented with the full command, which the user can
copy and paste and run.
But we can also have the wizard run the command for us.
OK, daddy, have you heard these ones before?
Dad Joke did.
Oh, seven bucks.
You'll find two FSC jokes.
Like I said, I did not test this ahead of time.
So here we are.
Dad Joke did.
OK, let's just... I have no idea how many times this
is coming back.
I know I'm over time.
I want to just close out by saying
there's a ton of other features in Effect CLI
that we've been working really hard on.
We've really made it our mission to help
you all be as lazy as I am.
We have tons and tons of things
you can do using config values
as fallbacks, which is really helpful for taking values out
of the environment for default values,
sharing parent commands with options and arguments
with child commands, which is a feature we've been asked
about numerous times by Johannes.
We had the ability to use args and options
to configure the environment for the command,
the whole prompt module, which wizard mode is built upon.
Tons more features.
We have a lot of ideas for features in the future.
And so yeah, with that, I encourage you all
to try out Effect CLI when you have
to build your next CLI application,
and then you can all thank me for building this library.
(audience applauds)
Wait, wait, wait.
Sorry.
10 seconds more.
10 seconds more.
Just kidding.
Don't thank me.
Thank you all very much for being here.
If you want the code, it's on my GitHub for this CLI.
And thank you all very much for your time.
I really appreciate it.
(audience applauds)
